anchor.surface_text: The matter has to be judged under the third proviso to s. 23A 1 , which read as follows Provided further that this sub-section shall number apply to any company in which the public are substantially interested or to a subsidiary company of such a company if the whole of the share capital of such subsidiary company is held by the parent company or by the nominees thereof.

holdings.text: The test followed by the Bombay High Court that no holding by the Directors of a company could be regarded as one in which the public were substantially interested is not the correct test

anchor.surface_text: We have heard Civil Appeal No. 30 of 1957 from the decision of the Bombay High Court in the Raghuvanshi Mills case  1 , in which judgment has been pronounced today, and have held that that is number the companyrect test to apply.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Court heard companion appeal from Raghuvanshi Mills, held Bombay HC test incorrect, set out correct test, remanded that case, and stated it applies equally here

holdings.text: The shares held by Mysore Merchants Ltd. could not be counted as part of the holding by the public and the High Court reached the correct conclusion on this

anchor.surface_text: It was., therefore, necessary for the High Court to companysider whether the shares held by Mysore Merchants Ltd., companyld be said to be held by the public. The High Court held against the assessee Company that they companyld number

holdings.reasoning_summary: Necessary to consider if Mysore shares count as public holding to reach 25%; High Court held they could not be counted as public and court agrees it is correct

holdings.text: To determine if shares held by another company are held by the public under the Explanation to s.23A, the paramount condition is that the public be beneficially interested in 25% of the voting power in that company; since Mysore Merchants Ltd. was a private company the public were not interested therein

anchor.surface_text: He points out that Mysore Merchants Ltd., had numberassessable income in the companyresponding assessment year and had suffered a loss, that companyditions  b  and  c  did number, therefore, apply, and that s. 23A is number applicable

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rejects petitioner's requirement of three conditions (public not interested, assessable profits, no 60% distribution); paramount is public beneficial interest in 25% voting power of Mysore which was admitted not as it was private company

holdings.text: In applying proviso and Explanation to s.23A, effect must be given to exclusion of company to which provisions of this sub-section apply, requiring determination whether Mysore Merchants Ltd. is such a company

anchor.surface_text: The matter has to be judged under the third proviso to s. 23A 1 , which read as follows Provided further that this sub-section shall number apply to any companypany in which the public are

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading requires applying words 'not including a company to which the provisions of this sub-section apply' to determine if holding company like Mysore falls within s.23A

holdings.text: Cl.14 of Part B States Taxation Concessions Order 1950 does not prevent application of s.23A to determine if shares held by Mysore Merchants Ltd. are those in which public beneficially interested; concession confers benefit but does not negative the test

anchor.surface_text: Learned companynsel for the assessee Company also companytended that in view of cl. 14 of the Part B States  Taxation Concessions  Order, 1950, the provisions of s. 23A companyld number be applied to Mysore Merchants Ltd.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Concession available if terms met but cannot detract from s.23A test under Explanation for public holding; order confers benefit, company may avail yet fall within s.23A for this purpose; contention has no force
